data.title: DSL: Difficult To Make A Case For This Bond Fund Today
data.description:
The DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund (DSL) is a closed-end fund that aims to provide its investors with a high level of current income. The fund does reasonably well in this task, as it boasts an 11.49% yield at the current share price, which is significantly higher than most other assets in the market possess. However, as is the case with all of the closed-end funds currently offered by DoubleLine, DSL achieves its objectives primarily by investing its assets into a portfolio comprised of bonds. Bonds only offer extremely limited upside when compared to common stocks, which is due to the simple fact that bonds are both issued and redeemed at their face values, so they offer no net capital gains when held over their lifetimes. As a result of this, investors in this fund should not expect to earn much beyond the distribution. Indeed, the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund has delivered no share price appreciation over the past ten years, and all of the returns that it has provided to its investors have come from the distribution. With that said, though, given the fact that this fund has a substantially higher yield than any of the benchmark bond indices, the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund should offer superior total returns to any exchange-traded index fund that tracks a bond index.

The DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund Versus Bond Index Funds

As mentioned in the introduction, the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund primarily invests its assets in bonds and similar fixed-income securities. The fund’s website states:

The Fund will seek to achieve its investment objectives by investing in a portfolio of investments selected for their potential to provide high current income, growth of capital, or both. The Fund may invest in debt securities and other income-producing investments anywhere in the world, including emerging markets.

This quote explicitly states that one thing that the fund’s management is looking for is an asset’s ability to provide growth of capital. As was mentioned in the introduction, most bonds are incapable of doing this as they are issued at face value and return the face value to their owners whenever the bond matures. As such, anyone who purchases a bond when it is first issued and holds it until it matures will have absolutely no growth of capital. Furthermore, anyone who purchases a bond at a price that is above its face value is actually guaranteed to have a negative growth of capital. It is not uncommon for bonds to trade at prices above their face values during periods of time in which interest rates are extraordinarily low. In fact, bonds will usually trade above their face values whenever the coupon rate on the bond is higher than what the same bond would have if it were issued today. Over the past fifteen years, market interest rates have typically been lower than they are today. However, prior to the financial crisis of 2008, bond yields were typically higher than during the period that followed it. As such, it has been extremely difficult, if not impossible, to actually achieve growth of capital from most bonds over the past few decades.

With that said, there are two types of bonds that can deliver growth of capital over their lifetimes. These two types are:

  1. Convertible bonds, if the bond is converted into common stock prior to its maturity date,
  2. Bonds that have a face value denominated in a currency that is different from the investor’s own home currency.

It is arguable whether the second type of bond is truly delivering growth of capital. This is because the bond’s gain comes from the investor’s home currency declining against the currency in which the bond is denominated. The bond itself did not actually deliver any increase in value because it still returns the same amount that was actually lent. All that has changed is that the investor’s home currency is worth less.

The DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund does not have any convertible bonds in its portfolio. However, it does have a number of foreign bonds. The most recent schedule of investments states that the fund had the following asset allocation as of December 31, 2025:

As we can see, the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund has no convertible bonds in its portfolio. As such, it is not using this particular asset class to generate growth of capital. It is also unlikely that the small allocation to common stocks will deliver any meaningful growth, given the companies that the fund is invested in:

Whenever a company goes bankrupt, it will sometimes convert its outstanding debt into common stock and issue this stock to the bondholders. It seems highly likely that DSL obtained its common stock positions via this method, given that several of these firms are not publicly traded and went through bankruptcy proceedings in past years. Thus, these are not so much investments as they are common stocks that the fund simply received along the way and now has no reason to sell (or is unable to sell) for whatever reason.

The DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund does, however, have relatively high exposure to foreign bonds. We can see that, as of December 31, 2025, fully 48.4% of the fund’s assets were invested in either foreign corporate bonds or foreign government bonds. This does not necessarily mean that these bonds are denominated in a currency other than the U.S. dollar, however. It is not uncommon for a company or a country to issue bonds denominated in U.S. dollars. In fact, this is very common among those entities that are based in emerging markets due to the simple fact that many international investors do not trust emerging market currencies. As such, the fund’s exposure to non-U.S. dollar-denominated bonds is likely lower than the 48.4% of net assets that the asset allocation chart suggests. The DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund, unfortunately, does not explicitly state what its foreign currency exposure actually is. However, given that the fund did have $37,305,132 (2.7% of net assets) invested in the DoubleLine Emerging Markets Local Currency Bond Fund (DBELX) as of December 31, 2025, it does have some foreign currency exposure. We just do not know exactly how much.

As the above chart shows, the portfolio of the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund essentially resembles that of a global bond fund. As such, it would be most appropriate to compare the fund to global bond indices. This chart clearly shows that the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund has a substantially better yield than any of the main American or global bond indices:

Index/ETF

Current Yield

Bloomberg U.S. Aggregate Bond Index (AGG)

3.85%

Bloomberg High Yield Very Liquid Index (JNK)

6.54%

Vanguard Total World Bond ETF (BNDW)

4.08%

Vanguard Total International Bond Index Fund ETF (BNDX)

4.35%

J.P. Morgan EMBI Global Core Index (EMB)

4.88%

As has been the case for quite some time now, the highest yielding of the major bond indices is the Bloomberg High Yield Very Liquid Index. This particular index tracks the price and yield performance of speculative-grade bonds issued by corporations in the United States. In other words, it tracks the price and yield performance of bonds in which the issuer is considered to have a high risk of defaulting on the bond. According to Moody’s, a BB-rated junk bond has a 1.5% chance of defaulting in any given year, and a B-rated junk bond has a 7% chance of defaulting in any given year. Naturally, whenever a bond issuer defaults, bond investors frequently lose all of the money that they invested in the bond. Despite the relatively high default risk, the American junk bond index only yields 6.54% at the current level. It is arguable whether or not this is actually high enough to compensate investors for the risk of loss here. After all, the yield of the junk bond index is only 2.69% higher than the yield of the investment-grade bond index (AGG), which consists of bonds that have a substantially lower risk of default.

As mentioned in the introduction, the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund has a yield of 11.49% at the current share price, so it is substantially higher than that of the American junk bond index. It is unclear whether or not the fund invests in riskier assets than those included in the index in order to achieve this outcome. The fund’s website provides the following breakdown of the credit quality of the bonds that comprise its portfolio:

As of January 31, 2026, the fund had 74.12% of its total assets invested in speculative-grade bonds. This is a lower percentage than the index possesses:

A junk bond is any bond rated Ba3 or lower. Thus, any index fund that tracks the Bloomberg High Yield Very Liquid Index will have 100% of its assets invested in junk bonds. That is a much higher allocation than DSL currently has.

However, the website for the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund does not break its assets down further than shown above. The website does not, for example, specify what proportion of the fund’s holdings consist of CAA1 and CAA2 bonds. It is possible that the junk bonds in the fund’s portfolio consist of the riskiest (and therefore highest-yielding) junk bonds on the market, while the JNK ETF only has a relatively small allocation to those bonds. Thus, unless DoubleLine provides a breakdown of the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund by the specific letter grades of the securities in the portfolio, we cannot be certain whether or not DSL is taking on greater risks than the index funds in order to achieve a higher yield.

However, one thing that we can be sure of is that the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund is using leverage as a method of boosting the effective yield that it earns from its net assets. The way that this works is that the fund borrows money and then uses the money that it borrows to buy bonds and similar debt securities. It then uses the coupons that it receives from these purchased securities to pay the interest on the borrowed money. If the bonds that the fund purchased pay more than is necessary to cover the interest on the fund’s debt, the fund is allowed to keep the surplus money. This ultimately results in the yield that the fund receives as a percentage of its net assets being higher than it would be if the fund did not use leverage. The fund’s most recent holdings report states that the fund’s portfolio consisted of securities that were worth $1,748,727,149 on December 31, 2025. However, the fund also had $388,984,550 in debt that it owed on that date. The net assets were only $1,359,742,599, but it collects coupon payments on the $1.7 billion amount. Thus, the fund’s income should actually be higher than it would be if the only assets that it controlled were the ones that were purchased with its net assets.

The most recent financial statements for the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund reinforce this conclusion. For the twelve-month period that ended on September 30, 2025, the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund received an income of $159,818,963 from the assets in its portfolio. This is an 11.28% yield on the fund’s average net assets of $1,416,805,329 over the period. This is clearly higher than any of the bond indices provide, and indeed, it is higher than just about any individual bonds provide. Thus, we can clearly see that the fund’s leverage is providing a boost to the effective yield that it earns from its net assets.

As was already noted, bonds deliver essentially all of their total returns through direct payments that they make to their investors. As such, for the most part, higher yields translate into higher total returns. This is true for many bond funds as well, not just for individual bonds. As the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund has a higher yield than any of the indices, we would therefore expect it to offer higher total returns than index funds tracking the major American or global bond indices. Indeed, this is what we see, as clearly shown here:

This chart shows the total return of the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund against the major bond indices over the past ten years. As is clearly shown, the fund managed to outperform all of the indices by a considerable margin. However, please note that the above chart assumes that an investor used the distributions that were paid out by each of these funds to purchase additional shares on the distribution payment date. This may not be a realistic assumption for bond investors, though, as many of those individuals who actually invest in bonds would prefer to take the distributions as cash.

Unfortunately, however, investors who actually take this fund’s distributions as cash end up disappointed. Over the past ten years, the share price of the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund declined by 29.42%. This was a substantially worse performance than any of the bond indices delivered over the same period:

The reason why the fund delivered a positive total return is that the distribution was sufficient to offset the entire share price decline and still leave the investors with profits. However, the fact that the fund’s share price declined by almost 30% suggests that the fund has not consistently covered the distributions that it pays out. After all, the share price of a closed-end fund typically correlates with its net asset value (although it is not as precise of a correlation as an exchange-traded fund experiences). This statement proves to be correct in this instance, as we can see in this chart:

This chart shows the share price of the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund compared to its net asset value (XDSLX). As we can see, both exhibited a very strong correlation with one another. Furthermore, the net asset value of the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund also declined over the period, as it declined by 33.16% over the ten-year period. The fact that the fund’s net asset value declined over the period means that the fund did not manage to cover its distributions over the period. While this is certainly concerning, it is worth noting that the fund cut its distribution in late 2020 following the losses that it suffered during the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, most of the net asset value decline was due to the fund continuing to pay out distributions throughout 2020 despite the massive sell-off of bonds in March, as well as the increase in interest rates during 2022. The bond market stabilized somewhat beginning in 2023, and the fund has done a better job maintaining its distribution since that time:

This is certainly an improvement over previous periods, but we can still see that the fund has been struggling to cover its distribution. Indeed, the fund’s net asset value is down over the period. As such, investors may want to use caution when considering purchasing shares of the fund.

The DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund Versus Other Bond CEFs

As was just discussed, the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund is able to employ certain strategies that allow it to earn a higher level of income and boast a higher yield than most bond index funds. This is not the only fund on the market that is able to use similar strategies, however. In fact, many closed-end bond funds are able to do so, and as a result, they are able to be much more competitive in terms of yield. We can see that here:

Morningstar Classification

Current Yield

The median yield of this group of eight closed-end funds is 11.25%, which is slightly below the yield of the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund. Thus, the yield of this fund should seem fairly reasonable to many income investors. We can see, however, that DSL also does not have the highest yield in the peer group. At its current level, its yield is only slightly above that of the median fund in the group. There are a number of funds with higher yields and thus a number of funds that will provide their investors with a higher level of income. Many income-seeking investors might be inclined to seek out other options given this. However, the fact that this fund does not have a particularly outsized yield relative to its peers suggests that the market is not pricing in a distribution cut. If it were, then the fund’s yield would be well above the median, as is the case with the abrdn Global Income Fund. As one of the things that we look for as income investors is a sustainable income, the fact that the market does not seem to expect a distribution cut is an attractive characteristic.

The correlation between yield and total return that we saw in the previous section does not necessarily apply when considering closed-end funds. As we can see here, the funds with the highest yields do not have the highest total returns over the trailing ten-year period:

Fund Name

Trailing Ten-Year Total Return

DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund

97.04%

BrandywineGLOBAL – Global Income Opportunities Fund

85.08%

MFS Multimarket Income Trust

95.52%

142.76%

PIMCO Dynamic Income Opportunities Fund

n/a

Putnam Premier Income Trust

66.40%

Western Asset Global Corporate Defined Opportunity Fund

68.53%

abrdn Global Income Fund

43.40%

The highest-yielding funds in this peer group are GDO and FCO, and we can clearly see that they were not the best funds to own in terms of total return. There is a reason for this, and it comes down to the fact that a closed-end fund can overdistribute. While it is generally not a good idea for a closed-end fund that is intended to last for perpetuity (as most of them are) to pay out more than its investment profits, there are no legal restrictions that forbid them from doing so. Indeed, a closed-end fund can technically pay out as much money as it wants to until its net asset value reaches zero. This seems to be the policy of the abrdn Global Income Fund, as its net asset value has been consistently declining over the past ten years:

As shown, the net asset value of the abrdn Global Income Fund has declined by 68.31% over the past ten years. As we already saw, this was worse than the net asset value decline suffered by the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund over the same period. Indeed, it is substantially worse. The cause of this is that the fund is distributing significantly more than it earns from its assets and destroying its net asset value in the process. As the fund’s net asset value declines, its share price also declines, and this decline in the share price offsets the high yield. As such, it is usually best to stick with a fund that is at least trying to keep its distributions in line with its investment profits. The DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund does much better here, although it was not the best fund overall over the past ten years.

Recent Performance Update

We last discussed the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund on July 10, 2025. As such, approximately seven-and-a-half months have passed since the last time that we looked at this fund. As we all know, many things can happen over a seven-month period. That was certainly the case with this one, and as such, there are a few things that we should discuss to understand the performance of this fund since that time.

One of the most important things that occurred over the past seven months that had an impact on bonds and bond prices is the resumption of the Federal Reserve’s attempts to ease monetary policy. This came in the form of three 25-basis point cuts to the federal funds target rate, which occurred in September, October, and December:

The effective federal funds rate was 4.33% the last time that we reviewed the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund. Today, it is at 3.64%, or 69 basis points below the July level. This is in line with the 75-basis points of cuts to the federal funds target rate, although the central bank did not manage to force the federal funds rate down by the entire 75 basis points. The current effective federal funds rate is in the target range, however.

We should note that the Federal Reserve only directly controls short-term interest rates. Long-term interest rates, such as those paid by most bonds, are not under the direct control of the nation’s central bank. This is why we can sometimes get situations such as what happened at the end of 2024, when the yields on long-term bonds rose despite the Federal Reserve reducing its benchmark federal funds target rate.

It was a bit of a different story in the current period, however. As was just mentioned, the Federal Reserve reduced its benchmark federal funds target rate by 75 basis points since July. This did not cause the interest rate on long-term bonds to rise as it did back in 2024. Rather, the coupon yields on long-term bonds declined in response to this event, although they did not decline by nearly as much as the federal funds rate did. We can see this here:

Bond Term

Yield on July 10, 2025

Yield Today

Ten-Year

4.35%

4.02%

Twenty-Year

4.87%

4.60%

Thirty-Year

4.86%

4.67%

For the purposes of this chart, I used the yield of U.S. Treasury securities of the specified term at the close of the market on the date mentioned. Corporate bond yields will be higher, but U.S. Treasuries generally give a pretty good idea of what the rest of the bond market is doing. As we can see, long-term U.S. Treasury yields have only declined by 19 to 33 basis points, depending on the term. This is far less than the decline in short-term yields that occurred over the period. As such, the yield curve has steepened.

Bond funds such as the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund mostly invest in notes and bonds, rather than in ultra-short-term bills. As we can see here, over half of the bonds held in DSL’s portfolio have maturity dates that are between 3 years and 5 years into the future:

As the yield curve has steepened, the bonds in the fund’s portfolio may not have seen their yields decline as much as would ordinarily be assumed, given 75 basis points of cuts by the Federal Reserve. Rather, while there likely have been some gains here, they would not have been as much as some investors would have hoped.

The fund’s performance since our last discussion has actually been far worse than we would have expected, even given the above considerations:

This chart compares the price performance of the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund with that of several of the major bond indices over the period from July 10, 2025, through today. We can see that the indices were up slightly, which is pretty much what we expected. However, the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund was down 6.09% over the period. This is not what we expected; however, it is in line with the fund’s net asset value performance over the same period:

We can see here that the net asset value of the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund has decreased by 4.00% since the last time that we looked at the fund. This occurred in spite of the bond market indices actually being up slightly, and it tells us that the fund clearly failed to cover its distributions over the past seven months. As such, caution may be recommended, as situations such as this could very easily result in a distribution cut if the fund’s management cannot correct this problem.

Even if we take the fund’s distributions into account, the DoubleLine Income Solution Fund substantially underperformed the bond indices:

Fortunately, we do see that the fund managed to deliver a positive total return over the period. The distributions that it paid out over the period were greater than the decline in the share price. However, investors still would have been better off with any of the index funds. The emerging market bond index fund, in particular, did very well, which may have been partly due to the fact that emerging markets in general have lower debt and less fiscal pressures than developed countries. Emerging market debt (particularly emerging market debt denominated in currencies other than the U.S. dollar) did remarkably well in 2025, and we can see that reflected above. While the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund does have some exposure to emerging market debt, it was clearly unable to capitalize on the strength in that sector as illustrated by its performance.

Forward Outlook For The Fund

While perhaps not as common as in 2024, it is still fairly often that I see financial commentators suggest that bonds will do fairly well as an asset class in 2026. The reasons for these calls usually revolve around predictions that the Federal Reserve will reduce interest rates this year and that inflation will decline. However, these two drivers might not be as good for bonds as some analysts expect.

One common suggestion in favor of bonds is that interest rates should come down as the Federal Reserve reduces interest rates. It is true that the Federal Reserve is expected to continue with its interest rate-cutting program that began back in 2024. Indeed, as of right now, the market believes that there is a 33.0% chance that there will be two 25-basis point cuts to the federal funds target rate by the end of this year:

Also, we can note in the chart above that the market believes that it is more likely that there will be three 25-basis point cuts than that there will be one cut by the end of the year. In fact, the market currently believes that there is a 59.3% chance that the federal funds target range will be cut by either 50 or 75 basis points by the end of this year.

There is an inverse correlation between interest rates and bond prices. Whenever interest rates decline, bond prices increase and vice versa. The argument for buying bonds, therefore, becomes that the Federal Reserve’s upcoming interest rate cuts will reduce interest rates all across the yield curve and thus cause bond prices to rise. There are two problems with this thesis. The first is that interest rates on bonds do not always decline whenever the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates. We saw this in the final three months of 2024. In fact, the yield of the ten-year U.S. Treasury note is higher today than it was on September 16, 2024. The reason that I chose that date is that it was the day before the Federal Open Market Committee met and made the decision to cut the federal funds target rate by 50 basis points (the first rate cut of the current cycle). On September 16, 2024, the ten-year U.S. Treasury note closed at 3.63%. Today, the ten-year U.S. Treasury note is at 4.02%, despite the federal funds target rate being 175 basis points lower than it was in early September 2024. Thus, interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve do not always lower the interest rates on bonds.

The second reason why the thesis about interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve is flawed is that the market is forward-looking. As we have just seen, the market currently expects the central bank to reduce the federal funds rate by 50 to 75 basis points this year. That expectation is already priced into bonds. Thus, if the Federal Reserve simply fulfills the market’s expectations, it is unlikely to move bond prices by very much. Therefore, any bond market profits that are likely to be made by 50 to 75 basis points of cuts have already been made.

The other part of the thesis that some analysts are making in favor of bonds is that inflation is coming down and will continue to do so. However, it is unclear whether or not inflation is actually coming down. On February 20, 2026, the Bureau of Economic Analysis released its personal consumption expenditures index for the month of December 2025. This report showed that this index increased by 2.9% year-over-year. That is higher than in any of the past four months:

In fact, that is the highest year-over-year increase in any of the past twelve months:

As we can see, the personal consumption expenditures index appears to generally show that inflation has been increasing since April 2025. The personal consumption expenditures index is generally considered to be a better indicator of the true rate of inflation than the Consumer Price Index. There are a few reasons for this, including the fact that the Personal Consumption Expenditures Index includes a broader range of goods and services consumed by individuals, and it also takes into account the price of things that are purchased by health insurance and similar products that make purchases on behalf of consumers. The Federal Reserve has historically considered the Personal Consumption Expenditures Index to be a more accurate measure of inflation, and it relies on it to make decisions about monetary policy rather than the Consumer Price Index.

As such, it is questionable whether or not inflation is actually coming down. The Consumer Price Index shows that it dropped in January, although it is still higher than in April 2025:

However, this measure still shows inflation hovering well above the Federal Reserve’s claimed 2% target, and it has been range-bound from 2.3% to 3% for the past twelve months. Unless this trend changes and inflation quickly declines and stays down, then there is not much room for bond yields to decline. After all, investors still want to get a positive real return on their bonds. It is difficult to see any catalyst that could push inflation down and keep it down for an extended period of time, given the borrowing needs of the U.S. government.

Thus, it is difficult to make a bullish case for bonds or bond funds right now. Most of the potential upside from interest rate cuts is already priced in, and bond yields cannot decline very much before they end up delivering negative real yields. As such, DSL seems somewhat unlikely to deliver much upside over the next twelve months.

Distribution Analysis

The website for the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund states that the fund has the primary objective of providing its investors with a high level of current income. This makes a lot of sense for a bond fund. In accordance with this objective, the fund pays a monthly distribution of $0.1100 per share ($1.32 per share annually), which gives it an 11.49% yield at the current share price.

Let us look at the fund’s most recent financial report, which is the annual report for the twelve-month period that ended on September 30, 2025, to see how well it is covering its distribution.

For the twelve-month period that ended on September 30, 2025, the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund reported a net investment income of $118,096,979. That was not sufficient to cover the $149,393,545 that the fund paid out in distributions over the period.

Unfortunately, the fund was not able to make up for the difference through capital gains. For the twelve-month period that ended on September 30, 2025, DSL reported net realized losses of $17,784,059, which were partially offset by $8,647,081 of net unrealized gains. The fund’s investment portfolio produced total returns of $108,960,001 over the period:

That was not sufficient to cover the distributions that were paid out over the period.

With that said, though, if we look back over the past two years, the fund did manage to cover its distributions. The fund’s portfolio produced total investment profits of $373,741,007 over the 24-month period that ended on September 30, 2025:

Over the same period, the fund paid out distributions totaling $288,852,317. Thus, it did manage to cover its distributions over the past two years. However, we can still see that the fund had to rely on its net unrealized gains to accomplish this. That could be problematic given that bonds always pay their face value at maturity (regardless of what the fund paid to get them) and unrealized gains are not necessarily permanent. As such, investors might still want to keep a watchful eye on the fund’s finances and watch its net asset value closely.

Valuation

Shares of the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund are currently trading at a 2.81% discount on net asset value. This is a slightly worse price than the 3.53% discount that the fund’s shares have had on average over the past month.

The fund’s current price is, however, reasonably in line with its long-term average. Over the past five years, shares of DSL have traded at prices ranging from a 14.20% discount to a 3.00% premium on net asset value. The average price over the five-year period was a 2.07% discount on net asset value. That is a slightly worse price than the fund has today.

The median price out of this group of eight funds is a 4.65% discount, so we can see that the current price of DSL is a bit above the peer median level. However, given that this is historically one of the more expensive bond funds around and that it is not particularly expensive compared to its long-term average price, the current price appears reasonable.

Expenses

The fund’s annual report states that it had an expense ratio of 2.98% for the most recent fiscal year.

Conclusion

In conclusion, the DoubleLine Income Solutions Fund is a closed-end bond fund that provides a far superior yield than that of most bond index funds. It is difficult to make a case for buying it though, given that the fund failed to cover its distribution in the most recent year and it has been suffering from falling net asset value. Furthermore, it is difficult to make a case for buying bonds in the current environment, given that interest rate cuts are already priced in, and inflation remains high enough to limit the degree to which interest rates can decline further before real rates become negative. The fund’s price appears to be reasonable compared to its historical range, however.

Editor's Note: This article covers one or more microcap stocks. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Block: AI Job Cuts Boost May Not Last For Long (Downgrade)
data.description:
Block: 40% Headcount Cut! Are You Serious?

Wow! Before I begin to discuss the thesis for investors in Block, Inc. (XYZ), I would like to express my heartfelt sympathies to the Block employees who are affected by this sweeping 40% single-day headcount reduction that CEO Jack Dorsey has decided to initiate.

There were already reported rumors of some kind of reorganization back in early February. But that reported figure was supposed to be 10%, not the 40% that we have come to know as of yesterday (February 26). So it must have baffled Block employees and investors, even though the market has reacted with palpable optimism.

I'm not going to go into whether the market is right or wrong to lift XYZ stock by almost 20% in the pre-market as I pen this update. It is my understanding that markets are amoral and that they react to KPIs (most of the time). And because of the potential of a markedly lower cost base due to the significant reduction in headcount, not only has guidance for XYZ improved in the near term, but the upgrade is also pretty significant. With that, I think you can make sense of why the market reacted like what we saw after the earnings report and conference. CFO Amrita Ahuja has the insights for us:

For Q1, we expect year-over-year gross profit growth of 22% to $2.8 billion. In addition to the growth momentum we're seeing, our guidance also reflects a smaller cost structure going forward. We believe the actions we're taking today will enable us to deliver faster product innovation for customers in the future while also enabling us to invest meaningfully in our business. With this change in cost structure, combined with the investments we plan to make, we are increasing our guidance for adjusted operating income in 2026 to $3.2 billion, reflecting year-over-year growth of 54% and 6 points of margin expansion relative to 2025. We are increasing our expectation for adjusted diluted EPS in 2026 to $3.66, also reflecting year-over-year growth of 54%. For Q1, we expect adjusted operating income of $600 million and adjusted diluted EPS of $0.67, reflecting year-over-year growth of 29% and 20%, respectively. Before wrapping up, a few additional considerations related to our guidance. Our Q1 operating income guidance includes a modest benefit from today's announcement, but we expect the organizational changes we announced today to begin to more meaningfully impact adjusted operating income in the second quarter with the full impact of our new cost structure more meaningfully improving profitability in the second half of the year. Given these timing dynamics and the pacing of investments in both risk loss and sales and marketing, we expect adjusted operating income margins to expand each quarter throughout the year from our Q1 starting point of 21%. We expect these margins to expand at a faster rate in Q3 and Q4 relative to Q2, and we expect to deliver just under 60% of our 2026 adjusted operating income guidance in the second half of the year. - Block Q4 2025 earnings call.

There you go. It is not a little bit of an increase, right? We are talking about a 54% growth in adjusted EPS for 2026 and also a 54% growth in adjusted operating income, or AOI, for the same fiscal year. Note that most of the benefits will flow through to the P&L in the second quarter and second half, as year-over-year growth guidance for Q1 is limited to about 20% on adjusted EPS. Hence, the market is reacting just like what we should expect the market to do. It does suggest that Block has finally moved from AI experimentation to productization successfully; otherwise, we wouldn't see it being reflected and emphasized as such by the CFO in the outlook commentary.

And we wouldn't see that Block CEO Jack Dorsey is so confident that he has decided to take it upon himself to announce these far-reaching layoffs to his organization. Now you see, Jack Dorsey has always been somewhat of an engineering person, if you are familiar with his background. While he may not necessarily be the best manager of talent, some could argue he has still been instrumental and influential in shaping narratives involving social media (he’s the co-founder of Twitter), Bitcoin (note that XYZ owns a reporting segment linked to it), and, of course, payments infrastructure.

Block's Two-Sided Flywheel Will Be Tested

On the latter, Block has penetrated firmly into the Gen Z consumer segment and also the SMB merchant opportunities. In other words, Block has consolidated a two-sided flywheel encompassing Cash App (consumer) and Square (merchant) in its fledgling ecosystem. Investors who have followed this company long enough before it changed its name to Block and ticker symbol to XYZ should know that back in the pandemic boom years, they also acquired Afterpay. And we all know that back then, tech companies were going after talent like nobody's business, snapping up everyone like "hotcakes," as bosses were concerned whether they could hire enough people due to the implication resulting from the pandemic.

Obviously, those crazy moments are now well behind us. Employment indicators have gone tepid, even though they are not showing any distress signals right now. However, consumer confidence is still at historically low levels, despite having some respite this month based on the latest reports.

Therefore, I think there is some justification that Block could have amalgamated a pretty sizeable headcount base that may not truly reflect the current era where AI could fundamentally alter the growth curve of its earnings projections. Let's not forget that the market has not been truly convinced about its investor day goals yet. Because if the market has full confidence in those targets, then why is XYZ still >80% below its pandemic-era highs when calculated from its recent bottom?

Of course we could point out that this situation is not unique to Block. In the fintech space, we have seen how PayPal (PYPL) has also suffered immensely at the hands of the shareholder class. PayPal also owns a two-sided network, but it probably hasn’t executed as well as XYZ in the merchant space. I guess that's why, when it comes to e-commerce, it has not been able to make significant gains and is underperforming the market average, as I discussed in a recent PYPL update.

Whereas, for Block, the current environment offers them another chance to regain the initiative and help the stock get out of its rut. The market needs more confidence, obviously beyond just headcount cuts. Nevertheless, the upgraded guidance for 2026, for now, shows that the company has a viable pathway to reaching its 2028 commitments.

In July last year, in my previous update on Block, I thought that the slide in the stock could come to an end. However, this proved to be premature, as the challenges that have affected fintech companies like Block persisted through the rest of 2025.

Block: Growth Reacceleration In The Works

I think the positive takeaway from the 2025 numbers is that the company is still fundamentally strong. It's already profitable, and it has integrated its diverse segments well, benefiting from the two-sided flywheel that I discussed earlier. This network effect has obviously gained traction even though the growth rates have slowed tremendously.

As we can see from the above chart, Block is now no longer considered a high-growth play. There are enough profitable companies out there outside the fintech space that are growing their profits above 20%. You can find them easily in the semiconductor space or even among the suppliers to the chip designers, as they supply the picks and shovels and the plumbing to help build out the AI infrastructure. And since we are still in the earlier stages of this multi-trillion-dollar phase, I believe management could also be concerned about when they will get that re-rating opportunity that could see the valuation return to a higher level.

Because it's important for us to understand that fintech companies are not your typical value or income stock in the financial sector. Value investors are not going to pay the current premium (17x forward earnings, as compared to financial media of <11x) attached to XYZ even before yesterday's post-earnings spike. These investors should very much prefer more stable big banking earnings predictability, as well as the dividend income that comes with their P&L, that are less susceptible to business cycle risks that could affect XYZ more significantly than the rest. After all, like I mentioned earlier, the company has a bigger exposure to the more vulnerable class in the consumer and merchant business.

Thus, I believe management must come out with something disruptive on their own to re-energize shareholders and potential growth investors to come back to its bullish narrative. And if you can put up guidance that suggests more than 50% growth in adjusted earnings, now that's something to get people’s attention, right? It certainly also got my attention, because if you look at the 2026 guidance, it suggests that gross profit growth could now be re-accelerating and laying a clearer pathway to reaching the 2028 imperatives.

What's important right now is that management has a lower OpEx base to work with, even though this is predicated very much on the success of its AI initiatives. It remains to be seen whether these are indeed transformational for the company, but I guess Block is astutely leveraging the zeitgeist that has made Claude Code the dominant media narrative and headlines in the past month, and particularly so this week.

For a stock that was valued at just under 17x forward earnings before the run-up, it is very below the S&P 500’s 21.4x forward earnings. In other words, there is much for XYZ to be re-rated if it manages to use the current organizational restructuring to drive constructive earnings growth.

Jack Dorsey was clearly generous with his words, as he wanted to use the opportunity to emphasize how deeply the company has integrated AI into its workflows, suggesting that this project has been an ongoing and multi-year initiative. So the 40% headcount reduction should not be construed as something it came up with at the last minute, given the current flux that we have in fintech on the street right now.

Dorsey’s commentary suggests to me that we could see an even tighter integration on its network and peer-to-peer capabilities. Therefore, it is not only going to be just the merchant side, but also the consumer side. This should drive improved operating leverage. As he explained, Block could "personalize" the products and services, which has the potential to improve the attach rates on its software integration, which is actually where Block really makes most of its money.

And so they have this dual-pronged approach in circulating the consumer and merchant flywheel to deliver a higher value proposition through a "better understanding of Block’s customers." I think the traction is really still very much uncertain in the current context. So I expect management to provide us more salient updates on how these AI initiatives could propel it closer to its 2028 goals. While investors have bid up the stock in view of the optimistic outlook, moving forward they will definitely want to see execution and clarity from the AI productization to be convinced that a longer time recovery could be taken as the norm and not the exception.

Buy Or Sell XYZ Stock?

Okay, I guess you can see that XYZ has been moving in a pretty predictable consolidation zone between the $45 level and the $80 level. With the pre-market prices moving the stock back up to the $65 zone, the situation has arguably stabilized, which should reduce the chances of seeing it fall back toward the February lows.

And since the $45 level has almost been tested twice, I don't expect the stock to drop below that level. Yet I also don't find enough longer-term catalysts after this current surge as the market attempts to price in the near-term benefits from a lower cost base, attributed to the organizational restructuring.

Moving from here, investors will likely press management for more answers on how it intends to execute such a massive reduction in its employee count. Without that level of certainty, it's challenging to envisage how Block could attract more buyers back as the valuation normalizes closer to the S&P 500 average.

Moreover, the ongoing economic uncertainties and weak consumer confidence levels could continue to weigh on its buying sentiments through the rest of 2026. And with the broad weakness in the financial sector potentially stymying efforts in elevating the bullish proposition, the coast is far from clear. This should require us to consider a larger discount to reflect these headwinds.

Rating: Downgrade XYZ to Hold.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Iridium: No Longer A Falling Knife, And We Have Growth Catalysts Ahead (Upgrade)
data.description:
Introduction

When industry refers to a stock as a "falling knife," it's usually because the stock has deteriorating fundamentals that the market is aware of, resulting in the stock repricing lower on a consistent basis. Stocks like these don't normally rerate higher unless a pivotal catalytic event occurs. This isn't the case with Iridium Communications (IRDM); the firm has solid fundamentals with management that has a propensity to return value to shareholders; however, the stock has been a laggard for multiple years now, which made me label it a "falling knife" in my previous article. To give you a perspective of how disappointing the price performance has been, just take a look at the YoY performance chart of IRDM vs. peers and the S&P 500. Iridium lost 22% in value, underperforming the 18% return from SPY, while ViaSat, Globalstar, and EchoStar returned 449.7%, 224.2%, and 277.6%, respectively.

The reason for this major underperformance has to do with the fact that the company has historically underinvested in growth while its industry was being invaded by multiple competitors like SpaceX and AST SpaceMobile. This made investors question the durability of Iridium's dominance in offering IoT and narrowband services to government and enterprises. Investor behavior was slightly different in the last 10 years compared to the current environment. Companies that were being too conservative with their use of cash were seen as ossified and had a greater chance of being disrupted by companies that were embarking on more ambitious goals. Since 2017, IRDM has reduced its CAPEX by roughly 80%, while competitors were going in the other direction.

Also, relative to peers, Iridium has been growing its top line at single digits, which in a way was validating to the market that the firm must have been slowly losing its pricing power in certain segments of its business, especially the broadband segment, which has been declining since 2023 as enterprises switched to using Starlink's constellation to access higher throughput and low-latency Ka and Ku bands and opted for Iridium's broadband services as backup. While growth rates are highly cyclical in this industry, IRDM hasn't been able to achieve YoY rates of more than 20%, while VSAT and GSAT would return more than 50% in a given year. In the last five years, Iridium returned a revenue CAGR of 8% vs. its peers ASTS, SATS, GSAT, and VSAT returning 36.39%, 51.56%, 15.58%, and 15.44%, respectively.

Investment Thesis

As a result of the stock continuing to decline, Iridium now trades at an attractive valuation relative to its sector and peers. But when the stock first showed up on my screens, I was wary to hit the bid, as momentum indicators were still in the red. Hence my initial hold rating. The momentum is finally positive, and there are growth drivers like the commercialization of NTN Direct and PNT ASICs in the middle of this year that are expected to boost topline growth by $200 million in 2030. However, the short-term catalyst for significant growth will likely come from third-party enterprises that are looking to utilize Iridium's L-band spectrum asset to offer a D2D network to its end consumers, but this is still in the speculation phase, but the likelihood of such an alliance is pretty high given that management did state in the last earnings call that it will not rule out business alliances that offer incremental value to shareholders.

In my previous article, I said Iridium had solid fundamentals, but it's a falling knife. Due to recent events, this sentiment has shifted. YTD, Iridium stock has outperformed its peers, returning 36%, while GSAT and SATS returned 3% and -1%, respectively. The scatter plot below makes a comparison between 1-year and YTD performance of a subset of stocks within the communication services sector that are close peers to Iridium. Iridium is in the second quadrant with one of the highest YTD performances, showing a mean-reversion behavior. This is also true with GSAT and SATS; they've massively outperformed peers last year, but YTD performance has disappointed. Given the B+ rating for momentum, I expect this positive momentum to continue, driven by Iridium's discounted valuation and the commercialization of NTN and PNT services, making me upgrade my initial rating from a hold to a strong buy.

Financial Analysis

FY 2025 Income Statement

For the full fiscal year results, revenue increased 5% to $871.55 million. Looking at segments, the growth was led by engineering and support growing 26% to $156.96 million, followed by commercial IoT increasing 9% to $181.38 million. Growth was offset by subscriber equipment declining 11% to $81.11 million and broadband declining 10% to $50.72 million. Cost of revenue increased by 8%, resulting in gross profits growing 4% to $623.66 million and landing gross margins at 71.55%, outpacing the sector margin of 53.56%. Operating and interest expenses decreased by 3%, leading to operating and pretax income increasing by 18% and 32%, respectively. Tax and other related expenses increased to $30.44 million, resulting in net income only increasing 1% to $114.37 million and landing net margins at 13.12%, also outpacing the sector margin of 3.98%.

FY 2025 Cash Flow Statement

Proving Iridium's operational efficiency, the firm only spent $7.69 million in working capital, resulting in operating and free cash flow growing 6% and 2% to the value of $400.07 million and $248.21 million, respectively. The growth in FCF was offset by capex increasing 43% to $100.28 million. This massive capex growth is in response to the company pausing buybacks to bolster growth through additional services. Management did state that it is not under pressure to invest in upgrading and growing its LEO constellation until 2031, freeing FCF for more dividend payouts and debt reduction. Despite FCF growing 2%, the margin still outpaced the sector median at 28% vs. 10.33%. SBC decreased 19% to $51.58 million, reflecting management's commitment to reducing stock dilution, as it stated that future compensation will be paid fully in cash, reducing stock issuance by 1%.

FY 2025 Balance Sheet

Iridium's balance sheet displays management's effort to reduce debt and lower interest expenses. Short-term debt decreased 90% to $3.4 million, while long-term debt was flat at $1.76 billion. Shareholder's equity decreased 20% to $462.6 million, resulting in a debt-to-equity ratio of 3.8x. While the balance sheet is still highly leveraged, the firm managed to retire debt that was maturing in the near term; most of the remaining debt matures in 2030, and given that the firm is a cash-generating machine with growth drivers ahead, I'm pretty confident the debt-to-equity ratio will get reduced to 2x as management intends.

Quantitative Analysis

Profitability

Looking at the profitability factor of Iridium in relation to its peers, we can see that it has one of the highest EBITDA and FCF margins, warranting it an A- rating by the Seeking Alpha Quant system. Even return of equity sits at 22%, while the sector median is at 5.93%.

Valuation

Given the outstanding profitability metrics, Iridium is well deserving of a premium valuation, which is yet to be assigned given that on an EBITDA multiple the firm trades at a discount to its sector peers and its historical 5-year rolling median. The trend line in the scatter plot illustrates that for a firm that trades at a price-to-cash flow of 6.20x, the fair value for the EBITDA multiple should be around 13x as opposed to the current multiple of 9.36x, implying a 39% stock upside.

Also, when we look at the median of its historical valuation, it sits at 16.69x. Both charts show how massively undervalued iridium is while returning margins that far exceed its peers.

As the firm increases the adoption of its PNT services through the installation of the ASIC device, this could push topline growth to high single digits by 2027-2028. The reason for this estimation has to do with the surging demand for surveillance services that will enable governments to track position, time, and locations of war assets like UAVs without jamming and spoofing risks, unlike with GPS. As we speak, PNT services are being used in Europe and Asia, and management stated they have realized well over $10 million in revenue and estimate realizing more than $100 million by 2030 during the Q&A of the call.

Risks

There are multiple execution risks associated with Iridium, the main one being that they are expected to commercialize NTN direct in the middle of this year while also expected to transition the PNT ASIC from the prototype to the commercial phase. Any faults or delays in any of these developments could result in the stock tanking, as this will reduce investors' confidence in topline growth. And also, given the fact that management has paused buyback, the cushion layer for drawdowns has been removed, leaving no protection for the downside risk.

Conclusion

My worries about Iridium have been lowered given the positive momentum that has built up since the start of this year. I have always been impressed by the fundamentals of the firm and management's commitment to return value to shareholders, but seeing that the stock had consistently dropped made me feel wary that we could be catching a falling knife. That is not the case anymore. The firm now has growth drivers that will definitely appeal to investors that over-index for topline growth, adding another class of investors on top of those looking for high profitability and shareholder yield. According to my model, we could see roughly 39% upside if Iridium were to trade in line with its sector on an EBITDA multiple, deserving of a strong buy rating.

data.title: CEOs Vs. The Treasury Market
data.description:
CEO confidence for the economic outlook has improved, but the Treasury market is still pricing in rate cuts.

The Conference Board reports that confidence among CEOs “surged” to the highest level in a year. “CEO Confidence improved significantly in the first quarter of 2026, reflecting restored optimism among leaders of large firms,” said Dana Peterson, chief economist at the consultancy.

The rebound in CEO optimism implies that the case for more Fed rate cuts has weakened. The Treasury market, however, has yet to be persuaded. The policy-sensitive 2‑year yield traded down yesterday to 3.44% (Feb. 26), holding near the lowest level in nearly four years and slightly below the current 3.50%–3.75% Fed funds target range.

Fed funds futures are still pricing in a pause in rate cuts for the next two policy meetings but anticipate another rate cut in June. Sticky inflation data and a steady, low jobless rate may complicate that forecast for a near-term cut. Markets will pay close attention to next week’s payrolls report for February, looking for new clues on where monetary policy is headed.

Another key variable is Kevin Warsh, the incoming Fed chair, who will take over the central bank’s leadership in May. Analysts are debating whether Warsh will tilt dovish to support President Trump’s demands for lower interest rates.

A complicating factor is the current nowcast for a rebound in economic growth for the first quarter. The Atlanta Fed’s GDPNow model, for example, is currently estimating that GDP will rise 3.1% in the first three months of this year, up sharply from Q4’s sluggish 1.4% increase.

The rise of artificial intelligence as an economic input is another variable that’s muddling the outlook. “The question is how is AI going to be inflationary, and maybe the long end of the curve is sniffing all of this out,” said Jack McIntyre, portfolio manager at Brandywine Global Investment Management. “The only inflationary aspect of AI is the building out of data centers and the associated energy needs, and that is known.”

If CEOs are right and growth is re-accelerating, the Treasury market is mispriced. If the bond market is right, CEO optimism is a head fake. With Warsh stepping in and AI reshaping the inflation debate, investors won’t have to wait long to find out who blinked first.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Whale's Insight: Surface Weakness Masks Whale Accumulation In ETH
data.description:
ETH is enduring its longest weekly losing streak since 2022, yet whale behavior quietly shifts to active accumulation at discounted prices. This edition highlights the contrast between surface-level pressure driven by Trump's tariff pivot, regulatory setbacks, the widely discussed 10am dump pattern that has sparked intense debate over whether Jane Street has truly manipulated Bitcoin's price, and underlying smart-money positioning in Ethereum (ETH-USD).

ETH Drops 6 Straight Weeks, Whales Shift to Active Accumulation

Despite ongoing ETH price pressure, on-chain and exchange data reveal layered whale behavior signals:

On Binance, average ETH whale sell order size has dropped from 2,250 ETH in early January to 1,350 ETH in recent weeks. The reduced order size indicates a clear slowdown in large-holder selling activity, which has temporarily thinned market depth and lowered the ability to absorb aggressive selling pressure in the short term.

Meanwhile, ETH has now recorded its sixth consecutive weekly loss, marking the longest uninterrupted weekly downtrend since the 10-week drawdown from March to June 2022. That earlier bear-market period eventually reached a cycle bottom before price stabilized, while the current streak, though shorter so far, continues to reflect persistent selling pressure and weak momentum on higher timeframes.

However, the realized price of ETH-accumulating whale addresses has bent downward for the first time, indicating no significant selling from these holders. Instead, they have been buying additional ETH at lower levels, which has pulled their average cost basis lower. In the region where realized price curves down, balances have surged and realized cap has increased, confirming net accumulation and growing capital commitment even as ETH trades near $2k.

Taken together, these signals show whales moving from gradual distribution toward active accumulation, not panic selling. Smart money appears to be building positions aggressively at discounted prices beneath the current surface weakness.

Trump's Tariff Pivot Ignites Inflation Fears, Crypto Clarity Collapses

Trump's Tariff Shockwave

On February 23-24, 2026, President Trump announced an immediate increase of global tariffs to 15%, pivoting to Trade Act Section 122 after a Supreme Court ruling struck down earlier tariff authorities.

This sudden policy shift rattled global markets, triggering a broad sell-off. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped, and Bitcoin (BTC-USD) fell below $65,000, erasing earlier gains.

This action introduces renewed inflation fears and complicates the Federal Reserve's potential path to rate cuts, creating a "higher-for-longer" interest rate environment that historically pressures high-beta assets like cryptocurrencies.

Regulatory Clarity in Peril

Market confidence in a definitive US crypto regulatory framework has largely evaporated. Prediction market odds for the landmark Clarity Act plunged from a recent high of around 82% to roughly half that level within just three days, driven primarily by stalled Senate negotiations over stablecoin rewards and broader legislative gridlock. This sharp reversal has revived concerns about a return to “regulation by enforcement,” driving institutional desks to de-risk.

At the same time, the Crypto Fear & Greed Index has stayed firmly in Extreme Fear territory throughout February. This ongoing regulatory uncertainty serves as a systemic drag on the market, outweighing other potential technical or on-chain improvements.

Key Crypto-Specific Catalysts

Amid this macro turmoil, project-specific events have exacerbated the downdraft:

  • Vitalik Buterin did sell 1,869 ETH for about $3.67 million over two days in late February 2026. This formed part of a larger pre-announced plan from late January, when he withdrew and allocated 16,384 ETH to support long-term Ethereum ecosystem initiatives. Although these sales were strategic and transparent, they added short-term market pressure and contributed to roughly a 5% decline in ETH's price during an already fragile period. This shows how extremely sensitive and fearful the current crypto market has become: reactions to the capital flows of key figures or institutions are often excessively amplified, gradually eroding rational market behavior in this environment.

  • Bitdeer, a leading Bitcoin mining company, fully liquidated its self-mined Bitcoin treasury, selling approximately 1,133 BTC for about $62 million, reducing its holdings to zero. The move aims to generate liquidity for AI cloud services expansion and data center land acquisitions. Similarly, in early Feb 2026, Cango miner sold 4,451 BTC for roughly $305 million to bolster its balance sheet and accelerate its pivot to AI infrastructure. More and more miners are shifting toward AI and data center infrastructure, using Bitcoin sales as a key financing strategy to fuel this pivot.

Did the 10am Dump Stop Bitcoin from Hitting $150K?

Since late 2024, Bitcoin has consistently experienced sharp sell-offs every trading day right around 10 a.m. Eastern Time, a pattern dubbed the “10am dump” by the crypto community.

In a viral long-form X post, Justin Bechler argues that this was executed by quantitative trading firm Jane Street. As an Authorized Participant for major Bitcoin spot ETFs like BlackRock’s IBIT (IBIT), Jane Street has privileged access to create and redeem ETF shares directly with real Bitcoin. This allows them to arbitrage discrepancies between the ETF’s NAV and the spot market price.

The author claims Jane Street leveraged this position by programmatically selling Bitcoin into the open market at 10 a.m., deliberately pushing spot prices lower to accumulate ETF shares at a discount.

The post points to Jane Street’s Q4 2025 13F filings showing $790 million in IBIT holdings but suggests these long positions were likely fully hedged or even net short via undisclosed derivatives like put options, short futures, or collar strategies. This masked any true bearish exposure while public disclosures showed bullish holdings.

The author estimates that without this daily suppression, Bitcoin’s price would already be at least $150k, far above current levels, highlighting how ETF mechanics may distort the asset’s true scarcity-driven value.

Notably, following a February 2026 federal lawsuit from Terraform Labs’ bankruptcy administrator accusing Jane Street of insider trading (tied to the 2022 Terra collapse), the 10am dump pattern abruptly ceased. Bitcoin then staged a strong V-shaped rebound, with the community interpreting this as legal and regulatory pressure forcing Jane Street to halt the alleged algorithm.

The thread exploded in popularity, sparking heated debates in crypto circles about institutional arbitrage transparency, ETF structural flaws, and Bitcoin’s suppressed price potential.

While some analysts counter that the pattern wasn’t consistent enough to prove systemic manipulation, and others point out that large market makers such as Jane Street have long possessed the technical ability to influence prices across many assets, though intentional manipulation is clearly illegal and not unique to crypto, the narrative has reignited scrutiny over who truly controls Bitcoin’s price discovery.

Week Ahead

  • Mar 1 Crypto Expo Europe

  • Mar 3 US ISM Manufacturing PMI Release

  • Mar 5 Employment Situation for February

  • Mar 5 U.S. Import and Export Price Indexes for January

Next week blends crypto community activity with key US macro data. Crypto Expo Europe may lift sentiment around exchange and Web3 developments. Macro releases including ISM Manufacturing PMI, February Nonfarm Payrolls, and January trade prices will influence inflation views and Fed rate expectations, keeping liquidity-sensitive assets like crypto on edge.

Disclaimer: The information provided herein does not constitute investment advice, financial advice, trading advice, or any other sort of advice, and should not be treated as such. All content set out below is for informational purposes only.

Original Post

data.title: Global Industrial: Trading At A Substantial Discount
data.description:
Executive Summary

Since then, I last covered Global Industrial Company (GIC) in May 2025. I found that despite its recent missteps, the stock was still trading at a discount. The misstep I am referring to was the acquisition of Indoff in May 2023, which was dilutive in terms of operating margins and shifted the company's focus away from expanding its lucrative Private Label portfolio.

Since then, GIC has continued to grow its topline better than expected, and more significantly, has expanded its gross margins. While the SD&A increase has been a drag, the YOY improvement in operating margins is a pleasant surprise. While the share price has gained 21% since, I still find GIC to be decently undervalued, both on an intrinsic basis and relative to its peers. For the stock to realize its potential, the management needs to continue this momentum on the top line, keep up the expanded gross margin profile, and successfully navigate the ever-changing tariff situation. If it can successfully accomplish this, the stock still has a good runway ahead of it - getting back to, and hopefully surpassing this time, its all-time high of around $45.

Investment Thesis

Global Industrial has cultivated a broad customer base over its 75-year history, ranging from small and medium-sized businesses to large enterprises like Walmart and Home Depot. Furthermore, the company has expanded its reach into the B2C segment through digital marketing efforts and continues to broaden its product portfolio and target customer segments, with recent inroads into public sector enterprises. Now, with a new CEO in place, it is re-targeting the larger strategic enterprise and governmental accounts—which tend to be more relationship-based, with higher average order size, and result in repeat customer orders. Being able to grow revenues at 4.8% in 2025 despite a 1% shrink in Q1 and in a year plagued with tariff vagaries is quite an achievement. The company seems to have begun a positive momentum streak, with 14% topline QoQ growth in Q4 and a 100 bps gross margin improvement YOY. This has translated into almost a 100 bps improvement in its operating margins.

On the flip side, the Selling, Distribution & Administrative (SD&A) expenses remain elevated, even more than 2 years after the Indoff acquisition. Given the strategic shift towards “high touch” sales, I reckon the SD&A will continue to be elevated, and therefore, operating margins will stabilize around 7.1%. It is important to note that GIC has managed to improve operating margins to 9% by 2022 from 5.8% in 2017.

Against this backdrop, I ran a Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) valuation analysis for GIC. I assumed next year’s topline growth will be a tad lower at 3%, given the continued macroeconomic uncertainty, and will gradually improve to the risk-free rate of 4%. Operating margins are assumed to increase over the period from 6.5% to 7.1%, driven by gross margin improvements. Historically, the company has not needed to invest much in Capex besides maintenance capital and additional working capital needs. I reckon this modus operandi will continue. Finally, the WACC for the company is 8.6%, which is lower than what I used previously, primarily driven by the recent drop in the US risk-free rate.

Using these inputs, the model yields an equity value of approximately $47/share. This represents a substantial 40% upside from the current share price of approximately $33.5.

FCFF Valuation Model ($ million)

Simulation Results

Results from the DCF model are highly dependent on the key assumptions outlined. The key variables under management control that will have a marked impact on valuation are related to the Private label mix, Private label margins, and overall cost control of the Selling, Distribution & Administrative (SD&A) expenses. Monte Carlo simulations were performed on the DCF model with these inputs as variables, with their values being drawn from the distributions shown in the table below. A set of 10,000 random iterations were executed, and the results from this simulation are shown in the figure below.

Frequency Plot Of Intrinsic Valuation From Monte Carlo Simulation

My intrinsic value range, derived from the simulation, provides a band from the 20th percentile of $40.5 to the 80th percentile of $52.9. With GIC currently trading around $33.5, it falls around the 3rd percentile of this range, indicating it is significantly underpriced and offers a substantial margin of safety.

Relative Pricing

To analyze how GIC trades relative to its peers, I selected a group of 23 public companies within the broader industrial distribution space. I regressed commonly used multiples against fundamental value drivers for each multiple. Based on these regression models, I calculated the predicted values of the multiples at which GIC should be trading, given its fundamentals (growth rate, margins, beta, payout ratio, ROC, etc.). I selected multiples where the regression R-squared was relatively high. As shown in the table below, GIC is currently undervalued across all four selected multiples. The valuation range derived from these relative multiples is $35 - $51. This confluence of intrinsic and relative valuation provides additional confidence in the thesis that GIC is currently trading at a discount. It should be trading close to its all-time high of around $45, which it has hit several times but has failed to break through that ceiling.
